revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = 13 Alabama Ghosts and Jeffrey | title_orig = | translator = | image = 13 Alabama Ghosts Jeffrey.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = Cover from the 2nd edition | author = Kathryn Tucker Windham
Margaret Gillis Figh | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = ''Jeffrey'' | subject = | genre = [[Folklore]] | publisher = Strode Publishers | pub_date = 1969 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print (hardcover) | pages = 120 pp ''(1st edition)'' | isbn = 0-8173-0376-6 | oclc= 16834379 | preceded_by = | followed_by = Jeffrey Introduces 13 More Southern Ghosts }} '''''13 Alabama Ghosts and Jeffrey''''' is a book first published in [[1969 in literature|1969]] by [[folklore|folklorist]] [[Kathryn Tucker Windham]] and Margaret Gillis Figh. The book contains thirteen [[ghost story|ghost stories]] from the U.S. state of [[Alabama]]. The book was the first in a series of seven ''Jeffrey'' books, most featuring ghost stories from a [[Southern United States|Southern state]]. Jeffrey in the book's title refers to a [[ghost]] that allegedly haunts Windham's home.{{cite web |title=Kathryn Tucker Windham |url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/face/Article.jsp?id=h-1582 |date=30 June 2008 |first=Frances Osborn |last=Robb |publisher=Encyclopedia of Alabama |accessdate=18 September 2009}}{{cite news| first=Jeremy| last=Gray| url=http://www.uasystem.ua.edu/Administration/News%20clips/Clips%20110405.pdf| title=The tale of the tale-teller| publisher=The Birmingham News| date=2005-10-30| accessdate=2009-09-17}} ==Origins of the book and Jeffrey== The foreword of the book describes how Windham came to be interested in ghost stories. It began with ghostly incidents in the Windham family home in [[Selma, Alabama|Selma]] that Windham attributed to a spirit she dubbed "Jeffrey". At first, the family heard footsteps in rooms that would later be found empty. A supposed photograph of Jeffrey, included in the book, was taken inside the home. On the night the picture was made, some young people visiting the house decided to play with a [[Ouija|Ouija board]], trying to contact Jeffrey. When they developed the photos taken that night, a shadowy vaguely human-like shape was seen beside a girl in the photograph. Soon after it was taken Windham contacted Figh, who was a noted collector of ghost stories, to ask about Jeffrey. Out of that meeting, the idea of ''13 Alabama Ghosts and Jeffrey'' was born.{{cite book | last =Windham | first =Kathryn Tucker |author2=Figh, Margaret Gillis | year =1969 | title =13 Alabama Ghosts and Jeffrey | publisher =Strode Publishers | isbn =0-8173-0376-6 }} In the preface to the book, Windham says that although there are many ghost stories in Alabama, she wanted to choose stories for her book that had "entertained many generations" and were "a treasured part of Southern folklore". Windham sought stories from which she could describe not only the ghost, but also the community and lifestyles of the people who first reported the haunting. Windham spends as much time describing the people and places around the ghost stories as she does the ghost itself. ==Stories included== * [[Rocky Hill Castle|The Ghost of the Angry Architect]] * [[Dr. John R. Drish House|Death Lights in the Tower]] * The Faithful Vigil at [[Kenworthy Hall|Carlisle Hall]] * The Specter in the Maze at [[Cahaba, Alabama|Cahaba]] * [[Eliza Battle|The Phantom Steamboat of the Tombigbee]] * The Unquiet Ghost at [[Gaineswood]] * The Face in the [[Pickens County Courthouse (Alabama)|Courthouse]] Window * [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile's]] Pipe-Smoking Captain * [[Sturdivant Hall|The Return of the Ruined Banker]] * [[Bill Sketoe|The Hole That Will Not Stay Filled]] * [[Red Lady of Huntingdon College|Huntingdon College's Red Lady]] * The Crying Spirit at the Well * The Dancing Ghost of [[Grancer Harrison]] ==Controversy== Despite being very popular in Alabama, the book attracted some controversy from certain Christians in the state who said that the book promoted beliefs incompatible with Christianity. In fact, Windham said that she had received letters from people telling her she is doomed to hell for writing the ''Jeffrey'' books. In an interview with ''[[The Birmingham News]]'', Windham responded to these claims, saying "If I'm going to hell — and I can't deny that, because it's not for me to judge — it won't be for telling ghost stories; I have far greater shortcomings than that." ==Adaptations== ''13 Alabama Ghosts and Jeffrey'' has been adapted into a stage musical by Don Everett Garrett and Kevin Francis Finn.{{cite web |title=13 Alabama Ghosts and Jeffrey |url=http://www.redmountaintheatre.org/1011-13-alabama-ghosts-and-jeffrey.html |publisher=Red Mountain Theatre Company |accessdate=23 June 2012}} Kathryn Tucker Windham gave her blessing for the adaptation and saw the premiere at Red Mountain Theatre Company's Cabaret Theatre in October 2010, prior to her death. The musical is now available to schools and arts organizations from the authors. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:1969 children's books]] [[Category:1969 short story collections]] [[Category:Children's short story collections]] [[Category:American short story collections]] [[Category:American children's books]] [[Category:Ghosts in written fiction]] [[Category:Books adapted into plays]] [[Category:Alabama in fiction]] [[Category:Alabama folklore]] [[Category:American ghosts]]

revision.text:
[[File:Eternal Rose Anyient.jpg|thumb|right| alt= Eternal Rose group performed as comedians in Singapore| Comedians performing together as part of the ''Htawara Hninzi'' troupe (Eternal Rose) in Singapore on 6 Mar 2011.]] '''Anyeint''' ({{MYname|MY=အငြိမ့်|MLCTS=a ngrim.}}; {{IPA-my|ʔəɲḛiɴ|IPA}}; {{lang-my|အငြိမ့်}}; also spelt '''a-nyeint''') is a traditional [[Burma|Burmese]] entertainment form that combines [[dance]] with instrumental music, [[singing|song]], and [[Sketch comedy|comedy routines]], in theatrical performances.<ref name="Seekins">Seekins, Donald M. (2006) "Anyeint (Anyeint Pwe)" ''Historical dictionary of Burma (Myanmar)'' Scarecrow Press, Lanham, Maryland, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zY5F88wiDYYC&pg=PA77 page 77], {{ISBN|978-0-8108-5476-5}}</ref><ref>[http://www.myanmars.net/myanmar-arts/myanmar-anyeint.htm Myanmar Anyeint, Myanmar theatre performance], [http://www.myanmars.net/ Myanmar Arts].</ref> It is a form of ''pwe'', the [[Burmese language|Burmese]] word for traditional entertainment. While classical ''pwe'' can be quite formal and almost ritualistic, ''anyeint'' is considered light entertainment.<ref name="Shepherd">Shepherd, John (2005) "Myanmar (Burma)" ''Continuum encyclopedia of popular music of the world: Volume 5 Asia and Oceania'' Continuum, page 197, {{OCLC| 493643751}}</ref>
In recent years, popular ''anyeint'' troupes such as Thee Lay Thee & Say Yaung Zoun ({{my|သီးလေးသီးနှင့်ဆေးရောင်ဆုံ}}) and ''Htawara Hninzi'' ({{my|ထာရဝနှင်းဆီ}}) have performed overseas, including [[Thailand]], [[Singapore]] and the [[United States]], which have large Burmese immigrant populations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=14749|title=Thee Lay Thee & Say Yaung zon|date=December 2008|work=The Irrawaddy|accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/2010/news/543/54315news.html|title=In Singapore, expatriates enjoy a traditional treat|last=Thein|first=Cherry|date=4 October 2010|work=Myanmar Times|accessdate=15 August 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110716172112/http://mmtimes.com/2010/news/543/54315news.html| archivedate= 16 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[VCD]]s of popular troupes' performances are also widely distributed; politically insensitive ones, including ''Say Yaung Zoun'' ({{my|ဆေးရောင်ဆုံ}}), have been banned by Burmese authorities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=9716|title=VCD Political Comedy Draws Laughter in Rangoon|last=Paung|first=Shah|date=27 December 2007|work=The Irrawaddy|accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref>
==Characters==
The lead singer and dancer in an ''anyeint'' performance is called the ''anyeint minthami'' ({{my|အငြိမ့်မင်းသမီး}}). Well-known film actresses and singers, including [[May Than Nu]] and [[Yadana Khin]], are often featured as lead ''anyeint'' actresses.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/no440/t001.htm |title=Myanmar TV show inspires young generation of comedians |author=Zon Pann Pwint |date=13 October 2009 |work=Myanmar Times |accessdate=15 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107223808/http://www.mmtimes.com/no440/t001.htm |archivedate=7 November 2011 }}</ref> The ''anyeint minthami'' dances to instrumental music and singing either [[a cappella]] or to music are interspersed with comedic dialogue and [[slapstick]] performed by clowns. The result is a sequence of solo and group dances. The costumes of ''anyeint'' performers are identical to those worn by puppets in traditional [[marionette]] theater.<ref>{{cite book|last=Falconer|first=John|author2=Luca Invernizzi Tettoni|title=Burmese design and architecture|publisher=Tuttle Publishing|year=2000|pages=218|isbn=978-962-593-882-0}}</ref> Although lead actresses were once the main focus of performances, the focus has now shifted to the comedic skits performed.
Slapstick comedians, known as ''lu shwin daw'' ({{my|လူရွှင်တော်}}) or ''lu pyet'' ({{my|လူပျက်}}, although this term is falling out of usage) provide entertainment while the ''minthami'' changes outfits.<ref name="diamond">{{cite journal|last=Diamond|first=Catherine|year=2000|title=Burmese Nights: the Pagoda Festival Pwe in the Age of Hollywood's ‘Titanic’|journal=New Theatre Quarterly|publisher=Cambridge University Press|volume=29|pages=227–248|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayFulltext?type=1&fid=3032132&jid=NTQ&volumeId=16&issueId=03&aid=3032124&bodyId=&membershipNumber=&societyETOCSession=|doi=10.1017/s0266464x00013865}}</ref> [[Zaganar]] and [[Kutho]] were successful comedians in early ''anyeint'' revival. In more recent times, well-known film actors and singers, such as [[Ye Lay]], [[Nay Toe]] and [[Htun Htun]], Kyaw Kyaw Bo, have featured as comedians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-TuZXkWGceiY/TkmAeIrNDSI/AAAAAAAAB6c/YVqHAh0kSHY/s1600/LA-HninSi+Poster_Aug27.jpg|title=LA ရင်ခွင်သို့နှင်းဆီ အငြိမ့်သဘင်နှင့် စတိတ်ရှိုး ကြေညာ|accessdate=15 August 2011|language=Burmese}}</ref> Comedians typically dressed in checkered-patterned Taungshay-style ''[[longyi]]'' (sarongs) and wear loose coats, a development innovated by [[U Po Sein]], an influential 19th-century performer.<ref name="diamond"/>
A small all-male music orchestra, led by the ''[[pattala]]'' (xylophone) music, accompanies the performance.<ref name="diamondc">{{cite journal|last=Diamond|first=Catherine|date=Spring 2009|title=A Delicate Balance: Negotiating Isolation and Globalization in the Burmese Performing Arts|journal=The Drama Review|volume=53|issue=1|pages=1054–2043|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/the_drama_review/v053/53.1.diamond.html}}</ref>
==Format== Anyeint performances begin with a recitation and explanation of ancient verses, followed by a ''pari kamma'' ({{my|ပရိကမ္မ}}), a formal speech by troupe members to introduce themselves and thank the show's patron.<ref name="diamondc"/> Comedians then provide an introductory slapstick skit, before inviting the lead actress to the stage for a performance, during which they will provide improvised jokes and playful insults to the audience.<ref name="diamondc"/> At the end of the dance set, comedians direct jokes at the actress, who rebuts them and defends herself.<ref name="diamondc"/>
In the past, the anyeint performance was concluded with a verse play called ''zat kyi'' ({{my|ဇာတ်ကြီး}}), although this portion is now omitted from contemporary anyeint programmes.<ref name="diamond"/>
==Origins==
The name "anyeint" comes from a [[Burmese language]] word meaning "gentle". The form originated as a royal court dance performed by female dancers and was originally confined to the royal court.<ref name="Seekins" /><ref name="diamondc"/> However, after the end of the Konbaung dynasty in 1885, anyeint troupes were forced to seek work outside and popularized a hybrid dance and comedic performance that has become popular throughout Burma,<ref name="Seekins" /> especially appealing to the growing [[merchant]] class in [[British Burma]], who patronised and sponsored these performances.<ref name="diamondc"/> The first known anyeint troupe was formed in [[Mandalay]] around 1900, by comedian U Chit Phwe and his wife, dancer Ma Sein Thone.<ref name="diamondc"/>
In the colonial era, famous anyeint actresses often became recording artists and were the headlines of anyeint shows, as composers wrote individual songs and dances suited to them.<ref name="diamondc"/> However, the importance of the lead actress has diminished.<ref name="diamondc"/> Anyeint reached its height in the 1970s, during a period of [[Burmese Way to Socialism|socialist rule]], with one of the most influential troupes being [[Mandalay]]'s ''Lamin Taya'' (The Hundred Moon Troupe).<ref name="diamondc"/> In 1973, the troupe's scriptwriter, Maung Myat Hmaing wrote ''Dancer of the Ganges'', which was one of the first Burmese plays to include the concept of democracy.<ref name="diamondc"/>
During the [[British Burma|colonial]], [[U Nu]] and [[Ne Win]] administrations, troupes commonly included political satire and critiques, including social commentary, as part of their skits.<ref name="Seekins" /> However, since 1988, regulations have become stricter, with comedians who perform political satire subject to arrest.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Guyot|first=James F.|date=Feb 1997|title=Burma in 1996: One Economy, Two Polities|journal=Asian Survey|publisher=University of California Press|volume=37|issue=2|pages=192|jstor=2645487|doi=10.1525/as.1997.37.2.01p0220s}}</ref> From 1988 to 1992, a military curfew at night prohibited all-night anyeint performances.<ref name="diamondc"/>
Since the release of the ''anyeint'' play ''Hninzi Thakhin'' ({{my|နှင်းဆီသခင်}}, lit. "Rose Master") in 2010, censorship of play contents have become stricter; the Myanmar Motion Picture Enterprise, the censorship body that regulates all ''anyeint'' troupes in the country, now mandates a full dress rehearsal to audit for any questionable content (such as jokes targeted at government officials, or cross-dressing scenes).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mizzima.com/news/inside-burma/5583-censorship-target-burmese-traditional-dance-troupes.html|title=Censorship target: Burmese traditional dance troupes|last=Phanida|date=12 July 2011|work=Mizzima News|accessdate=13 July 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110712225351/http://mizzima.com/news/inside-burma/5583-censorship-target-burmese-traditional-dance-troupes.html| archivedate= 12 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The Burmese comedian, [[Zarganar]], has frequently performed in anyeint.<ref>[http://www.moemaka.org/index.php?view=article&catid=81:news&id=263:thee-lay-thee-a-colorful-anyeint-burmese-performance-troupe-a-success-in-san-francisco&option=com_content&Itemid=44 Thee Lay Thee & Colorful Anyeint, Burmese Performance Troupe, a success in San Francisco], [http://www.moemaka.org/ MoeMaKa], February 2, 2009.</ref> In 1986, he formed the Mya Ponnama Anyeint troupe, whose performances have appeared on television. The Burmese performance art [[Htein Lin]] has also performed anyeint, which is an influence in his [[performance art]].<ref>[http://www.freezarganar.org/Htein-Lin.asp Htein Lin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430181701/http://www.freezarganar.org/Htein-Lin.asp |date=2010-04-30 }}, [http://www.freezarganar.org/ Free Zarganar].</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Dance}}
[[Category:Arts in Myanmar]] [[Category:Asian dances]] [[Category:Singing]] [[Category:Burmese words and phrases]]

page.title: Australian Institute of Architects Gold Medal

revision.text:
{{primary|date=January 2015}} The '''Gold Medal''' is the highest award of the [[Australian Institute of Architects]] awarded annually since 1960. The award was created to recognise distinguished service by [[Australia]]n architects who have: * designed or executed buildings of high merit; * produced work of great distinction resulting in the advancement of architecture; or * endowed the profession of architecture in a distinguished manner.
Until August 2008, the Institute traded as the ''Royal Australian Institute of Architects'' and the award was called the ''RAIA Gold Medal''. ==Winners== * [[1960 in architecture|1960]] [[Leslie Wilkinson]] * [[1961 in architecture|1961]] [[Louis Laybourne-Smith]] * [[1962 in architecture|1962]] [[Joseph Fowell]] * [[1963 in architecture|1963]] [[Stephenson and Turner|Arthur Stephenson]] * 1964 [[Cobden Parkes]] * 1965 [[Bates Smart|Osborn McCutcheon]] * 1966 [[William Laurie (architect)|William Laurie ]] * 1967 [[William Godfrey (architect)|William Godfrey]] * 1968 [[Roy Grounds]] * 1969 [[Robin Boyd (architect)|Robin Boyd]] * 1970 [[Jack McConnell (architect)|Jack McConnell]] * 1971 [[Frederick Lucas (architect)|Frederick Lucas]] * 1972 [[New South Wales Government Architect|Ted Farmer]] * 1973 [[Jørn Utzon]] * 1974 [[Raymond Berg]] * 1975 [[Sydney Ancher]] * 1976 [[Harry Seidler]] * 1977 [[Ronald Gilling]] * 1978 [[Mervyn Parry]] * 1979 [[Bryce Mortlock]] * 1980 [[John Andrews (architect)|John Andrews]] * 1981 [[Colin Madigan]] * 1982 [[John Overall (architect)|John Overall]] * 1983 [[Gilbert Nicol]] & [[Ross Chisholm (architect)|Ross Chisholm ]] * 1984 [[Philip Cox]] * 1985 [[Richard Norman Johnson]] * 1986 [[Richard Butterworth]] * 1987 [[Daryl Jackson]] * 1988 [[Romaldo Giurgola]] * 1989 [[Robin Gibson (architect)|Robin Gibson]] * 1990 [[Peter McIntyre (architect)|Peter McIntyre]] * 1991 [[Donald Bailey (architect)|Donald Bailey]] * 1992 [[Glenn Murcutt]] * 1993 [[Ken Woolley]] * 1994 [[Neville Quarry]] * 1995 no award * 1996 [[Denton Corker Marshall|John Denton, William Corker & Barry Marshall]] * 1997 [[Roy Simpson (architect)|Roy Simpson]] * 1998 [[Gabriel Poole]] * 1999 [[Richard Leplastrier]] * 2000 [[John Morphett (architect)|John Morphett]] * 2001 [[Keith Cottier]] * 2002 [[Brit Andresen]] * 2003 [[Peter Corrigan]] * 2004 [[Gregory Burgess]] * 2005 [[James Birrell]] * 2006 [[Kerry Hill]] * [[2007 in architecture|2007]] [[Enrico Taglietti]] * [[2008 in architecture|2008]] [[Richard Johnson (architect)|Richard Johnson]] * [[2009 in architecture|2009]] [[Ken Maher]] * [[2010 in architecture|2010]] [[Kerry_and_Lindsay_Clare|Kerry Clare and Lindsay Clare]] * [[2011 in architecture|2011]] [[Graeme Gunn]] * [[2012 in architecture|2012]] [[Lawrence Nield]]<ref>{{cite news | title =2012 Gold Medal – Jury Citation for Lawrence Nield| work = | publisher =Australian Institute of Architects | date = | url = http://www.architecture.com.au/i-cms?page=1.64.34.15164.23890| accessdate = 27 March 2012}}</ref> * [[2013 in architecture|2013]] [[Peter Wilson (architect)|Peter Wilson]]<ref >{{cite web |url =http://architectureau.com/articles/2013-gold-medallist/|title =Peter Wilson awarded 2013 Australian Institute of Architects Gold Medal | author= |date = |work = |publisher =Architecture Media Pty Ltd|accessdate =26 April 2013}}</ref> * [[2014 in architecture|2014]] [[Troppo Architects|Phil Harris and Adrian Welke]] * [[2015 in architecture|2015]] [[Peter Stutchbury]] * [[2016 in architecture|2016]] [[ARM Architecture (Ashton Raggatt McDougall)|ARM Architecture]]<ref>[http://www.thefifthestate.com.au/innovation/design/arm-architecture-scoops-gold-medal-at-architecture-awards/82026 "ARM Architecture scoops Gold Medal at Architecture Awards"] in ''The Fifth Estate'', 2 May 2016</ref> * [[2017 in architecture|2017]] [[Peter Elliott (architect)|Peter Elliott]]<ref>{{cite web|url= https://architectureau.com/articles/2017-national-prizes-gold-medal/|title=2017 National Prizes: Gold Medal|publisher=Architecture Media Pty Ltd|date=6 May 2017|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> * [[2018 in architecture|2018]] [[Alexander Tzannes]]

revision.comment: /* History and profile */http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''''Bonytt''''' is a [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] monthly home and [[interior design]] magazine based in [[Oslo]], Norway. Founded in 1941, it is one of the oldest magazines in the country as well as the most popular magazine in its category.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Thomas Berker|author2=Helen Jøsok Gansmo|title=Paradoxes of design: energy and water consumption and the aestheticization of Norwegian bathrooms 1990–2008|journal=Sustainable Development|date=June 2010|volume=18|issue=3|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/sd.454/abstract|accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref>
==History and profile== ''Bonytt'' was established in 1941.<ref name="gra">{{cite book|author=Grace Lees-Maffei|title=Writing Design: Words and Objects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GV9gAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA47|accessdate=18 June 2016|date=12 September 2013|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-84788-957-7|page=47}}</ref> The founders were Arne Remlow and Per Tannum.<ref name=gra/> Ramlow was the owner and long-term [[editor-in-chief]] of the magazine,<ref name=gra/> which has its headquarters in Oslo.<ref name="pub">{{cite news|title=Factsheet. Bonytt|url=http://www.adnative.net/home/media-solutions/media-search/media-factsheet-detail/mediadata/bonytt/?PARAM1=MO2BO1#.V2WVqJOLTVo|accessdate=18 June 2016|work=Publicitas}}</ref> In 1947 the magazine become the official media outlet of the Norwegian Applied Art Association.<ref name=gra/> In the 1950s it adopted a modernist approach, which was left later.<ref name=gra/> Then it positioned itself as a source for inspiration for the amateur [[interior designers]].<ref name=gra/> In 1967 the magazine was renamed as ''nye bonytt'' to indicate its new approach.<ref>{{cite book|author=Grace Lees-Maffei|title=Writing Design: Words and Objects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GV9gAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA47|accessdate=18 June 2016|date=12 September 2013|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-84788-957-7|page=50}}</ref>
The magazine is part of [[Egmont Group|Egmont]]/[[Orkla Group|Orkla]] ASA.<ref name="nor">{{cite web|title=Consumer magazines: Top ten titles by circulation/issue 2006|url=http://www.nordicom.gu.se/sites/default/files/medieforskning-statistik/1131_2030_Cons_mags_top10_2006.xls|work=Nordicom|accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref> It is published monthly by Egmont Hjemmet Mortensen A/S.<ref name="pub"/>
In 1999 ''Bonytt'' had a circulation of 711,000 copies, making it the best-selling consumer special interest magazine in Norway.<ref>{{cite web|title=Major Magazine titles (1999)|url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/zanran_storage/www.fipp.com/ContentPages/998500250.pdf|work=FIPP|accessdate=18 June 2016}}</ref> The circulation of the magazine was 68,000 copies in 2003.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Europa World Year: Kazakhstan - Zimbabwe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gP_-8rXzQs8C&pg=PA3231|accessdate=9 July 2016|year=2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis Group|isbn=978-1-85743-255-8|page=3231}}</ref> In 2006 the magazine sold 62,900 copies.<ref name=nor/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{italic title}}

'''BookBlast'''® Limited, a writing agency based in [[Tonbridge]], was founded in 1997 to showcase new or neglected writers and world writing.
==Description==
The agency numbers three directors: Georgia de Chamberet, Ben Fiagbe and Jemma Jupp; company secretary M. N. Jenks; legal advisor Alan Williams; and three editorial freelancers. The agency also offers Franco-British translation services.
Clients include Jamika Ajalon (Zenzile), Rupert Bogarde, M. V. Diboll, Edward Evans, Philip Mann, [[Mounsi]] and Onyekachi Wambu, editor of ''Empire Windrush: Fifty Years of Writing About Black Britain''. ''[[The Bookseller]]'' referred to the anthology as being "ground-breaking, tracking how black men and women have made Britain their own".<ref>[http://www.writersservices.com/reference/bookblast-ltd BookBlast Ltd] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222200550/http://www.writersservices.com/reference/bookblast-ltd |date=December 22, 2015 }} at Writer Services.</ref><ref>http://www.authorsclub.co.uk/?page_id=63</ref><ref>[https://soundcloud.com/bookblast/mounsi-interviewed-by-harriett Mounsi interview] by Harriett Gilbert for ''The Word'', BBC World Service.</ref>
Estates: [[Lesley Blanch]] (1904-2007) in association with United Agents, Professor [[George Elton Mayo]] (1880–1949) and Gael Elton Mayo (1923-1992).<ref>[https://soundcloud.com/bookblast/radio4-lesley19jan Lesley Blanch] BBC Radio 4.</ref><ref>[http://www.londonbookfair.co.uk/en/Contributors/301208/Georgia-de-Chamberet Georgia de Chamberet profile]. The London Book Fair.</ref>
[[XCiTés]]: the Flamingo Book of New French Writing, edited by Chamberet, features writing by 15 writers under 40 who were unknown in English when the book was published in 2000 — [[Frédéric Beigbeder]], [[Tonino Benacquista]], [[Virginie Despentes]], [[Michel Houellebecq]], [[Abdourahman Waberi]] among them.
Chamberet has written for [[3:AM Magazine]] and [[Words Without Borders]] and The BookBlast® Diary.
== Awards == * Abdourahmann Waberi's ''The Gallery of the Insane'' published in [[XCiTés]]: the Flamingo Book of New French Writing, was shortlisted for The Caine Prize in 2000. * Mounsi's ''The Demented Dance'' (''La noce des fous'') was awarded the 2004 Inaugural 3:AM Good Sex Prize.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2004/nov/27/featuresreviews.guardianreview4</ref> * In 2015 the agency's website bookblast.com (first online in 2000) was selected by the curators of Bodleian Electronic Archives and Manuscripts, [[Bodleian Libraries]], Oxford, as being of lasting research value and worthy of permanent preservation in the Web Archive of the Bodleian Libraries.<ref>https://archive-it.org/home/bodleian?q=bookblast.com</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *Official site http://www.bookblast.com/

[[File:Study naked no1906 Villeneuve-164.jpg|thumb|Photograph by [[Julien Vallou de Villeneuve]] (1854)]]
'''Buttock cleavage''' is minor exposure of the [[buttocks]] and the [[intergluteal cleft]] between them, often because of [[low-rise pants]].
The crena is another formal term for the cleft between the buttocks, and the medical term is posterior rugae.
==History== When faced with indecency issues back in the 1930s, W.G. Cassidy explained in an essay titled ''Private Parts: A Judicial View'' that exposure of a buttock cleavage may come under "other private parts" in Australian law, though indecency generally involves exposure of the [[genital area]].<ref>Cassidy, WG. "[http://search.informit.com.au/documentSummary;dn=972822724348847;res=IELLCC Private parts: A judicial view", ''Southerly'' (Vol. 34, No. 3), pages 315-319, Sep 1974]</ref>
In the early [[2000s in fashion|2000s]] it became fashionable for young women and men to expose their buttocks this way, often in tandem with [[Low-rise jeans|low rise jeans]].<ref name="Salon">Brown, Janelle. [http://www.salon.com/mwt/style/2002/05/28/booty_call/ "Here come the buns"], ''[[Salon.com]]'', URL accessed March 12, 2006.</ref><ref>Jennifer D'Angelo, "[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,40105,00.html Cleavage Fashion Flips Upside Down]," FOXNews.com, December 5, 2001, URL accessed 12 March 2006.</ref> ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'' called it the "new cleavage", and expressed views that "It's virtually impossible to find jeans to cover your hipbone".<ref>Daugherty, Gina. [http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2003/05/29/tem_thurslede29.html "Thong spotting gets easier"], ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'', May 29, 2003.</ref> In August 2001, ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' celebrated a "bum cleavage week" claiming that "bums are the new tits".<ref>Davies, Anna. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/aug/27/gender.uk "Bum deal: Suddenly, women's bottoms are everywhere. It might seem like jolly, harmless fun, but actually there's nothing innocent about it"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', August 27, 2001. Accessed February 19, 2008. "Last week was bum cleavage week at the Sun."</ref> In reaction to this trend, ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' aired a [[parody advertisement]] in their April 16, 2006 episode for a product called ''Neutrogena Coin Slot Cream'', in which host [[Lindsay Lohan]] appeared.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sCF8ZOYVXF8 |title=Saturday Night Live Skit - Neutrogena Coin Slot Cream |publisher=Youtube.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-01}}{{Verify credibility|date=August 2012}}</ref>
British designer [[Alexander McQueen]] was particularly mentioned as the originator of buttock cleavage-revealing jeans, known as the "bumster", in cultural critique [[Sheila Jeffreys]]' ''Beauty and Misogyny: Harmful Cultural Practices in the West''.<ref>Sheila Jeffreys, [https://books.google.com/books?id=UAi55tsTffgC&pg=PA98&dq=buttock+cleavage&lr=&ei=mF-7R5DyJobosQPYluChBQ&sig=-fHUmClfc1tQCQz_bUe0Sk6jwfI Beauty and Misogyny: Harmful Cultural Practices in the West], page 98, Routledge, 2005, {{ISBN|0-415-35183-9}}</ref> United States Patent 6473908 from 2002 registers a design for trousers with a removable buttock cleavage-revealing portion.<ref>[http://www.patentstorm.us/patents/6473908-description.html Garment having a buttocks cleavage revealing feature], Patent Storm</ref> In the mid-2000s, ''[[Good Morning America]]'' reported on a rise of popularity of the buttock cleavage among celebrities.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=125903&page=1 "Celebrities Are Showing Off Butt Cleavage"], ''[[Good Morning America]]'', July 25. Accessed February 19, 2008.</ref>
[[File:Luna Star at Exxxotica NJ 2013.jpg|thumb|upright=0.6|left|A model in very short [[shorts]] with exposed underbuns]]
In 2010s, media reported rise in popularity among females of ultra-short [[miniskirts]] and [[shorts]], which publicly exposed [[underbuns]] (i.e. lower part of [[buttocks]] - also referred as [[wikt:underbutt|underbutt]]s or "reverse buttock cleavage"), due to endorsement by such celebrities as [[Lady Gaga]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/life/799234/underbun-pictures-reddit|title=WHAT is the underbun? THIS is the latest sexy body trend taking over the web (May 4, 2017)|publisher=[[ Express Newspapers]]|accessdate=26 Jan 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/style-beauty/fashion/news/a4583/butt-cleavage-2013/|title=HIGH ALERT: We're All Helpless Onlookers To The Summer of Butt Cleavage (July 17, 2013)|publisher=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]|accessdate=26 Jan 2018}}</ref>
==Lexicon== [[File:Belt Failure (234582464).jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|"Plumber's crack"]]
The terms ''plumber butt'' or ''plumber's crack'' (Canadian, Australian and American English) and ''builder's bum'' (British English) refer to the exposure of male buttock cleavage, especially on occasions of careless bending over. The expression "builder's bum" was first recorded in 1988. The terms are based on the popular impression that work in these professions frequently involves bending over in locations where bystanders are observing from the rear.<ref>"Brewer's Dictionary of Modern Phrase & Fable", by John Ayto, Ian Crofton (2006) {{ISBN|0-304-36809-1}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=3DiHy31K30oC&pg=PA121&dq=%22plumber%27s+butt%22+-wikipedia&ei=wS_ASITTD4PSswOtiKHXDA&sig=ACfU3U3-edJh9qb_z6Z7sVelCB-SpsIMsA p.121]</ref>
In the Netherlands the term {{lang|nl|bouwvakkersdecolleté}} and in Germany {{lang|de|maurerdekolleté}} and in Poland {{lang|pl|dekolt hydraulika}} is used, which can be translated as "builder's/mason's/plumber's [[Cleavage (breasts)|cleavage]]". In France, it is usually referred to as {{lang|fr|le sourire du plombier}}, which translates to "the plumber's smile".
==See also== {{Commons category|Intergluteal cleft}} * [[Butt crack]] * [[Cleavage (breasts)|Breast cleavage]] * [[Intergluteal cleft]] * [[Camel toe]] * [[Wardrobe Malfunction]] * [[Whale tail]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Added explanation of charge conjugation, which was missing.
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2008}}
'''Charge conjugation''' is a transformation that switches all particles with their corresponding antiparticles, and thus changes the sign of all [[charge (physics)|charges]]: not only [[electric charge]] but also the charges relevant to other forces. In [[physics]], '''C-symmetry''' means the symmetry of physical laws under a charge-conjugation [[transformation (mathematics)|transformation]]. Electromagnetism, gravity and the strong interaction all obey C-symmetry, but [[weak interaction]]s violate C-symmetry.
==Charge reversal in electroweak theory== The laws of [[electromagnetism]] (both [[classical physics|classical]] and [[quantum]]) are [[Invariant (physics)|invariant]] under this transformation: if each charge ''q'' were to be replaced with a charge −''q'', and thus the directions of the [[electric field|electric]] and [[magnetic field]]s were reversed, the dynamics would preserve the same form. In the language of [[quantum field theory]], charge conjugation transforms:<ref name="PS">{{cite book|author1=Peskin, M.E. |author2=Schroeder, D.V.|title=An Introduction to Quantum Field Theory|publisher=Addison Wesley|year=1997|isbn=0-201-50397-2}}</ref>
# <math>\psi \rightarrow -i(\bar\psi \gamma^0 \gamma^2)^T</math> # <math>\bar\psi \rightarrow -i(\gamma^0 \gamma^2 \psi)^T</math> # <math>A^\mu \rightarrow -A^\mu</math>
Notice that these transformations do not alter the [[Chirality (physics)|chirality]] of particles. A left-handed [[neutrino]] would be taken by charge conjugation into a left-handed [[antineutrino]], which does not interact in the Standard Model. This property is what is meant by the "maximal violation" of C-symmetry in the weak interaction.
(Some postulated extensions of the [[Standard Model]], like [[left-right model]]s, restore this C-symmetry.)
==Combination of charge and parity reversal== It was believed for some time that C-symmetry could be combined with the [[parity (physics)|parity]]-inversion transformation (see [[P-symmetry]]) to preserve a combined [[CP-symmetry]]. However, violations of this symmetry have been identified in the weak interactions (particularly in the [[kaon]]s and B [[meson]]s). In the Standard Model, this [[CP violation]] is due to a single phase in the [[CKM matrix]]. If CP is combined with time reversal ([[T-symmetry]]), the resulting [[CPT-symmetry]] can be shown using only the [[Wightman axioms]] to be universally obeyed.
==Charge definition== {{main|C parity}}
To give an example, take two real scalar fields, ''φ'' and ''χ''. Suppose both fields have even C-parity (even C-parity refers to even symmetry under charge conjugation e.g., <math>C\psi(q) = C\psi(-q)</math>, as opposed to odd C-parity which refers to antisymmetry under charge conjugation, e.g., <math>C\psi(q)=-C\psi(-q)</math>).
Define <math>\psi\ \stackrel{\mathrm{def}}{=}\ {\phi + i \chi\over \sqrt{2}}</math>. Now, {{mvar|φ}} and {{mvar|χ}} have even ''C''-parities, and the imaginary number ''i'' has an odd ''C''-parity (''C'' is anti-unitary). Under ''C'', ''ψ'' goes to ''ψ<sup>*</sup>''.
In other models, it is also possible for both ''φ'' and ''χ'' to have odd C-parities.
==See also== * [[C parity]] * [[Anti-particle]] * [[Antimatter]] * [[Truly neutral particle]]
==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite book|author=Sozzi, M.S.|title=Discrete symmetries and CP violation|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|isbn=978-0-19-929666-8}}
<!-- footer templates --> {{C, P and T}}
<!-- categories --> [[Category:Quantum field theory]] [[Category:Symmetry]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Use British English|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Clarance Holt | birth_name = Joseph Frederick Holt | birth_date = {{Birth date|1826|01|09|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Marylebone]], [[London]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|1903|09|27|1826|01|09|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Bloomsbury]], England | occupation = [[actor-manager]] | years_active = 1846–1893 | spouse = Marian Vaughan | children = Ellen Elizabeth Holt
Elizabeth May Holt
Joseph Thomas Holt }} '''Clarance Holt''' (9 January 1826 – 27 September 1903), born '''Joseph Frederick Holt''' was an English [[actor-manager]] who had a successful career on the stage in England, Australia and New Zealand. His company included his wife and, frequently, his three children, all of whom went on to have successful careers on the stage. ==Early life and career== He was born on 9 January 1826 in [[Marylebone]], London the youngest son of Thomas Holt and Elizabeth Giddens. His father was a successful military tailor with an establishment (Thomas Holt & Son) in [[Piccadilly]]. He was variously described in his younger days as actor, acrobat and comedian and eventually adopted the stage name of Clarance. Holt made his stage debut in 1842 as Timothy in [[William Thomas Moncrieff]]'s farce ''All at Coventry'' at the Victoria Theatre, London.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/ouractorsandact00pascgoog|title=Our Actors and Actresses|publisher=archive.org|date=|accessdate=2014-10-20}} He married Marian Browne (sometimes named Marian Vaughan) in 1847 and they were acting together by 1850 when he was appointed manager of the [[Theatre Royal, Norwich]] under the name of Joseph Clarance.{{cite web|title=A Detailed History of Norwich Theatre Royal|url=https://secure.theatreroyalnorwich.co.uk/Online/default.asp?doWork::WScontent::loadArticle=Load&BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::article_id=F1DCA31C-5488-47B3-9480-99AF0226DD18|website=Norwich Theatre Royal|publisher=Theatre Royal (Norwich) Trust|accessdate=21 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mandmclark.com/index.htm|title=Clark family history|publisher=mandmclark.com|date=|accessdate=2014-10-20}} ==Career in Australia and New Zealand== Holt went to [[Melbourne]] with his wife in September 1854 at the suggestion of [[George Coppin]]. From Geelong he went to [[Hobart Town]] and [[Launceston, Tasmania]] and in September 1855 opened at the Prince of Wales Theatre in [[Sydney]]. Before leaving Australia in April 1857 he had played in most of the goldfields centres of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and performed on 330 nights. In 1858 he returned to Melbourne with his family on board the Josephine. A successful tragedian, Holt played Othello to [[Gustavus Brooke]]'s Iago; in 1862 as joint lessee of the Theatre Royal, Melbourne, he engaged such players as Brooke, [[Anna Bishop]], [[Joseph Jefferson]] and others. When the lease ran out he went to [[Dunedin]] and "became the pioneer of the English drama in [[New Zealand]]" by establishing the theatre there.{{cite web|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/holt-joseph-thomas-bland-3785|title=Bland Holt|publisher=adb.anu.edu.au|date=|accessdate=2014-10-20}}{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/ouractorsandact00pascgoog|title=Our Actors and Actresses|publisher=archive.org|date=|accessdate=2014-10-20}} ==Later Career in England== In September 1864 he returned to England{{cite news|title=Amusements|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=ODT18640812.2.19.2|accessdate=21 October 2014|work=Otago Daily Times|issue=825|date=12 August 1864}} and went into partnership with Charles Wilmot and they managed a number of theatres including the City of London Theatre, The Duke’s Theatre, Holborn, The Islington Theatre and the Lyceum Theatre, [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]]. In addition to managing these theatres he continued to perform and tour the provinces. He also created a successful one man touring show – ''A Night with Shakespeare and Dickens'' and in 1870 wrote, produced and starred in an adaptation of [[Les Miserables]]– ''The Barricade''. He retired from the stage in about 1893. ==Personal life== He was married three times: to Marian Browne in 1847, Alice Hayes in 1883 and Hannah Harris in 1893. His three children; Ellen Elizabeth (Nellie), [[May Holt|Elizabeth May (May)]] and [[Bland Holt|Joseph Thomas (Bland)]] all became actors.{{cite book |last=Newey |first=Katherine |editor1-last=Schafer |editor1-first=Elizabeth |editor2-last=Bradley Smith |editor2-first=Susan |title=Playing Australia : Australian Theatre and the International Stage |publisher=Rodopi |date=2003 |pages=93–107 |chapter=Chapter 6: When Is an Australian Playwright not an Australian Playwright? The Case of May Holt |isbn=978-9-042-00817-5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mandmclark.com/index.htm|title=Clark family history|publisher=mandmclark.com|date=|accessdate=2014-10-20}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holt, Clarance}} [[Category:English male stage actors]] [[Category:English male Shakespearean actors]] [[Category:19th-century English male actors]] [[Category:19th-century theatre]] [[Category:Actor-managers]] [[Category:1826 births]] [[Category:1903 deaths]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=December 2016}} {{Orphan|date=December 2016}} }}
'''Daisy Sylvan''' (July 12, 1874 - Unknown), born '''Elena Mazzantini''', was an Italian film studio owner, producer, director, and actress in the silent era. She was the founder of Daisy Film, which produced ...''Bolscevismo??'' (...''Bolshevism,'' 1922) and ''Sovrana'' (''Sovereign,'' 1923), both considered [[lost film]]s.
==Early life and career== Sylvan was born Elena Mazzantini in [[Rome]] on July 12, 1874. Her parentage is unknown, although it is unlikely that she was born to aristocrats, as was once thought.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/daisy-sylvan/|title=Daisy Sylvan – Women Film Pioneers Project|website=wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref>
Little is known about Sylvan's early life and career. It is likely that she studied with well-known actor and acting coach Luigi Rasi in [[Florence]].<ref name=":0" /> In 1918, Sylvan announced that she had written two film scripts, presumably for ...''Bolscevismo??'' and ''Sovrana''.<ref name=":0" /> In 1919, Sylvan legally established her own production company, Daisy Film, located on Via Strozzi in Florence.<ref name=":1">Martinelli, Vittorio. “Les metteuses-en-scène.” ''Cinemasessanta: bimestrale cinematografico di cultura'' 9-10 (Settembre-Ottobre 1981)20-25, 47.</ref> Both films were completed in 1920, though seemingly not distributed until 1922 and 1923, respectively.<ref name=":0" /> Sylvan was plagued by accusations of union violations throughout her tenure as studio head. Records suggest that Sylvan may have unlawfully terminated workers at Daisy Film, though it is likely that these infractions were amplified in the press by Sylvan's professional rivals.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== ''...Bolscevismo??'' == While this film in not extant, promotional materials show that ''...Bolscevismo??'' was a morality play set during the Russian Revolution. ''...Bolscevismo??'' was based loosely on the novel ''The'' ''Flame in the Steppe'' by Danilo Korsakoff.<ref name=":1" /> The film tells the story of sisters Elena and Enelia Morgani, both played by Sylvan. Elena is represented as hardworking and good while Enelia is shown to be disloyal and morally corrupt. Indeed, one pamphlet for the film suggests that Enelia has stolen Elena's husband. Elena, Sylvan's namesake and surrogate in the film, manages workers at a factory in a town called Selenio. A vicious Bolshevik journalist named Zobisant sets out to destroy Elena's personal life and career. Ultimately, Elena defeats Zobisant, leaving him begging for her forgiveness at the end of the film.
This film was shot largely on location in Florence, with some scenes filmed at Daisy Film's small studio.
Sylvan began working on ...''Bolscevismo'' around 1918 and completed filming by 1920, according to news sources.<ref>''Contropelo'' 24 (12 giugno 1920): 3.</ref><ref>Cardini, Gino. “Un bel casetto…” ''L’arte Italiana. Giornale del teatro e del Cinematografo'' 10-11 (1918): 3.</ref> Though passed by censors and distributed in 1922,<ref>Strazzulla, Gaetano, and Duccio Baldassini. “Il (non) mistero di Daisy Sylvan.” ''Immagine'' 33 (1995-1996): 25 – 27.</ref> the film was never shown theatrically.
== ''Sovrana'' == Like ''...Bolscevismo??'', ''Sovrana'' is considered a lost film. Existing promotional materials suggest that the film was based on a comedic play by [[Dario Niccodemi|Dario Nicodemi]]. The plot concerns a young woman, Giana, who is rescued from the underworld by actor Luigi Rasi (Daisy Sylvan's real life mentor). It seems that the film's title, ''Sovrana (Sovereign),'' refers to the protagonist's rejection of romantic overtures, choosing instead to remain "sovereign of her heart."<ref name=":0" />
== Personal life == Sylvan married Francesco Rosso in Rome in 1897.<ref name=":0" /> The couple officially separated in 1902,<ref>Pepi, Leonardo. ''Elena Mazzantini alias Daisy Sylvan, pioniera del cinema muto italiano''. Thesis, University of Florence, 2008, 15.</ref> though remained legally married until Rosso's death in 1920. Sylvan and Rosso had at least one child (a son) together.<ref name=":0" />
== References ==
<references />
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sylvan, Daisy}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:Italian film producers]] [[Category:Italian film directors]] [[Category:Italian women film directors]] [[Category:Italian film actresses]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:Women film pioneers]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2011}}
'''Digital Live Art''' <ref name="DLA">Sheridan, J.G. (2006). "Digital Live Art: Mediating Wittingness in Playful Arenas". PhD Thesis. University of Lancaster: Lancaster.</ref> is the intersection of [[Live Art (art form)]], [[Computing]] and [[Human Computer Interaction]] (HCI). It is used to describe live performance which is computer mediated - an orchestrated, temporal witnessed event occurring for any length of time and in any place using technological means. Digital Live Art borrows the methods, tools and theories from HCI to help inform and analyze the design and evaluation of Digital Live Art experiences.
== Theory == Central to the understanding of Digital Live Art is the concept of performance [[framing (social sciences)]]. First identified by [[Gregory Bateson]],<ref>Bateson, G. (1955). A Theory of Play and Fantasy. Psychiatric research reports, 2, 39-51.</ref> the performance frame is described as a cognitive context where all the rules of behavior, symbols, and their interpretations are bound within a particular activity within its own structure. The concept has since been used extensively in ethnography by [[Erving Goffman]] in his discussions of face to face encounters in the everyday, in discourse structures;<ref>Tannen, D. Framing in Conversational Structures. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1993.</ref> in theatrical and ritual events;<ref>Schechner, R. The Future of Ritual, Writings on Culture and Performance. Routledge, New York, 1993.</ref><ref>Turner, V. From Ritual to Theatre: The Human Seriousness of Play. PAJ Publications, New York, 1982.</ref> sporting events and festivals;<ref>MacAloon, J. editor. Rite, Drama, Festival, Spectacle. Institute for the Study of Human Issues, 1984.</ref> and trance phenomena <ref>d’Aquili, E., Laughlin, C. D., and McMannus, J. editors. The Spectrum of Ritual jacks . Columbia University Press, 1979.</ref> (see:<ref>Rush, M. Security art. Journal of Performance and Art - PAJ, 26(1):113–115, January 2004.</ref>).
Goffman’s work uses the concept of performance frame to broadly mean a constructed context within the limits of which individual human agency and social interaction takes place. For example, a theatrical frame,<ref name="Goffman">E. Goffman. Frame Analysis: An Essay on the Organization of Experience. Harper and Row, 1974.</ref> pp. 124–155) involves the construction of a higher-level frame on top of a ‘primary framework’, i.e., the reality in which the fantasy takes place. In this example, actors assume a character, audiences suspend disbelief and events have their meaning transformed (e.g., compare the use of a mobile phone in public with its use in a theatre). Additionally, framings are temporal, meaning that they have specific beginning and endings. While many theorists argue that all social interaction may be seen from a dramaturgical perspective, meaning all everyday social interaction becomes performance in some sense,<ref name="Goffman"/> Digital Live Art theorists often deliberately align their work with [[Richard Schechner]],<ref>R. Schechner. Performance Theory. Routledge, 1988</ref> narrowing their analysis to cover more stabilized ‘established’ forms of performance so that performance framing is defined as an activity done within the intended frame ‘by an individual or group’ who have some established knowledge about the frame, and are ‘in the presence of and for another individual or group’.<ref>Benford, S., Crabtree, A., Reeves, S., Flintham, M., Drozd, A., Sheridan, J.G., Dix, A. The frame of the game: Blurring the boundary between fiction and reality in mobile experiences. In Proceedings of SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI), April 2006</ref> Performance framings then, are intentional, temporal and for an audience.
== Method and Tools == The goal of interaction in Digital Live Art goes beyond that of traditional HCI methods and theory which focus on usability, functionality and efficiency. HCI and [[CSCW]] models often focus on workplace activities and their tasks, artefacts and goals. This research often leads to a better understanding of how to increase efficiency in the workplace by providing more efficient and usable interfaces. For example, one could conduct [[usability testing]] or [[task analysis]] of how a DJ uses his DJ decks and one could then use this information to design a more efficient system.
However, traditional HCI models tell us little about how the performer-audience relationship develops as a result of users wittingness to interact with the system. The intention with Digital Live Art is not to make more "usable" systems but rather to allow for "participatory transitions"<ref name="DLA"/> - transitions between "witting and unwitting",<ref name="DLA"/> between observation and participation, between participation and performance. Since the goal with Digital Live Art systems is to "mediate wittingness"<ref name="DLA"/> rather than task-focused interaction, the application of many HCI models, frameworks and methods become insufficient for analyzing and evaluating Digital Live Art.
=== Performance Triad Model === Sheridan first introduced the '''Performance Triad Model''' <ref>Sheridan, J.G., Dix, A., Lock, S. and Bayliss, A. (2004) Understanding Interaction in Ubiquitous Guerrilla Performances in Playful Arenas. S. In Fincher, P. Markopolous, D. Moore, & R. Ruddle (Eds.): In People and Computers XVIII-Design for Life: 18th British HCI Group Annual Conference, pp. 3-17, Springer-Verlag, 6–10 September, Leeds, UK. {{ISBN|1-85233-900-4}}.</ref> for analyzing "tripartite interaction" - interaction between observers, participants and performers. In the Performance Triad Model, tripartite interaction where technology binds tripartite interaction to context and environment. Reeves et al.<ref>S. Reeves, S. Benford, C. O’Malley, and M. Fraser. Designing the spectator experience. In Proceedings of SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI), April 2005.</ref> draws a distinction between a performer and a spectator and how their transitioning relationship as mediated by the interface.
=== Formal Method === Dix and Sheridan<ref>Dix, A., Sheridan, J.G., Reeves, S., Benford, S. and O'Malley, C. (2005) Formalising Performative Interaction. In Proceedings of the 12th International Workshop on Design, Specification and Verification of Interactive Systems (DSVIS), pp. 15-25, Springer Lecture Notes in Computer Science, 13–15 July, Newcastle, UK.</ref> introduced a [[formal method]] for analyzing "performative interaction"<ref name="DLA"/> in Digital Live Art. This formal method provides a mathematical technique for deconstructing interaction between witting and unwitting bystanders and observers, participants in the performance and the performers themselves. The work attempts to formalise some of the basic attributes of performative interaction against a background of sociological analysis in order to better understand how computer interfaces may support performance. This work shows how this generic formalisation can be used in the deconstruction, analysis and understanding of performative action and more broadly in live performance.
== Key People/Groups == [http://www.bigdoginteractive.com BigDog Interactive]

page.title: Film Employees Federation of South India

revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox Union |name= Film Employees Federation of South India |country= India |affiliation= Tamil Film Directors' Council, [[Nadigar Sangam]] |members= |full_name= |image= |founded= {{start date and age|1967}}<ref>http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/8930/14/14_chapter%209.pdf</ref> |office= [[Vadapalani]], [[Chennai]] |people= |website= |native_name= |current= |head= [[R. K. Selvamani]] |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |footnotes= }} The '''Film Employees Federation of South India (FEFSI)''' is an Indian organisation consisting of technicians from the [[Tamil cinema|Tamil film industry]] in [[Tamil Nadu]], [[India]]. A total of 22 unions belonging to different trades in the film and television industry are affiliated to the FEFSI that has around 25,000 members.
==Strikes== ===June 1997=== In June 1997, some members of the FEFSI resorted to a flash strike during the shooting of the film ''[[Raman Abdullah]]'', directed by [[Balu Mahendra]], protesting against the director engaging "outsiders". This led into a major crisis when FEFSI launched an indefinite strike, affecting other film units as well.<ref>http://m.rediff.com/news/jul/07madras.htm</ref> The state government's intervened and FEFSI called off the strike after a week. However, the producers hardened their stand and insisted that they would not engage any technician or worker associated with FEFSI. They complained that the rising wages of technical staff and artistes were contributing towards the box office run of Tamil films in 1997.<ref>http://m.rediff.com/entertai/jun/17mad.htm</ref> They demanded that workers and technicians form new organisations exclusively for the production of Tamil films, on the lines of organisations in Kerala and Andhra Pradesh. The issue escalated when the organisation's leader [[Vijayan (stunt coordinator)|Vijayan]] declined to budge from his demands and was able failed to gather support from a series of prominent actors and film director [[Bharathiraja]].<ref>http://www.indolink.com/tamil/cinema/News/97/Oct/strike.htm</ref> vijayan also became the key person for the strike which led to suicide of some members and some lost their asserts due to this strike.
Films delayed included ''[[Marudhanayagam]]'', ''[[Jeans (film)|Jeans]]'', ''[[Sethu (film)|Sethu]]'' and ''[[Kadhal Rojave]]''. Producer [[K. T. Kunjumon]] said his losses amounted to {{INR}} 3 [[lakh]]s after a large set he had erected for his film ''[[Ratchagan]]'' (a replica of the massive Rajaji Hall) was destroyed in the rain. Several new Cielo cars parked near the set were also damaged, resulting in a loss of another {{INR}} 7 lakhs, he claimed.<ref>http://m.rediff.com/entertai/jun/30mad.htm</ref> The strike lasted for over six months, delaying the production of several films before easing. In June 1998, FEFSI and the Tamil Film Producers Association (TFPA) merged and formed a new organisation called the Tamil Nadu Film Producers and Employees Federation. An agreement to this effect was signed by the representatives of the two organisations in the presence of then Chief Minister [[Muthuvel Karunanidhi]].<ref>http://www.tribuneindia.com/1998/98jul06/nation.htm</ref>
===June 2011=== Talks between FEFSI and the Tamil Film Producers Council (TFPC) over wages and working hours became a heated matter in early 2011 and FEFSI members wanted the issue regarding increase in salary to be sorted out immediately, calling for a strike in June 2011.<ref>http://www.sify.com/movies/fefsi-to-strike-from-monday-news-tamil-lgflWVajbbi.html</ref>
===February 2012=== An unofficial two-week strike was held in early February 2012, with nearly 5000 members of FEFSI engaging on a day-long hunger strike at Isai Kalaignargal Sangam in Vadapalani, demanding that the Tamil Film Producers Council (TFPC) implement the revised wages for its members. The strike was made official briefly in April 2012 but did not disrupt any big-budget film productions, and soon the problems were eased out after the intervention of the State's Labour Minister [[S. T. Chellapandian]].<ref>http://behindwoods.com/tamil-movies-cinema-news-10/clash-brings-kollywood-to-a-standstill-fefsi-strike-29-05-13.html</ref><ref>http://www.moviecrow.com/News/824/fefsi-strike-fails-as-tamil-movies-carry-on</ref><ref>http://www.sify.com/movies/fefsi-calls-off-strike-rumblings-in-tfpc-news-tamil-melj3Bebfgd.html</ref>
===June 2013=== A clash broke out when the drivers' union learnt that one of the camera crews supposedly hired a private agency for their logistics, instead of approaching the assigned drivers and this was contrary to union expectations.<ref>http://behindwoods.com/tamil-movies-cinema-news-10/clash-brings-kollywood-to-a-standstill-fefsi-strike-29-05-13.html</ref> After brief disturbances in May 2013, FEFSI announced a decision to boycott all vehicles of the drivers’ union. In June 2013, FEFSI announced that they would go an indefinite strike after it was alleged that members of the drivers union had assaulted members of the technicians union at Nerkundram Paadhai on Monday, when they were loading food into an autorickshaw for a film shoot.<ref>http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/unions-clash-puts-film-shoots-on-hold/article4760404.ece</ref> Two days later the strike was cancelled and film shootings resumed.
As a fallout of the strike, the Tamil Nadu Chinna Thirai Producers Council president [[Raadhika]] announced that the council had decided to break away from FEFSI.<ref>http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/film-technicians-union-calls-off-strike-shoots-to-resume/article4763699.ece</ref>
leaders *May 2009 - Writer [[V. C. Guhunathan]] was elected and pledged to improve conditions and work closely with producers.<ref>http://mobiletoi.timesofindia.com/mobile.aspx?article=yes&pageid=4&sectid=edid=&edlabel=TOICH&mydateHid=14-10-2009&pubname=Times+of+India+-+Chennai&edname=&articleid=Ar00405&publabel=TOI</ref> He quit in 2011 shortly after the 2011 State elections results were released and departed from his post simultaneously with [[Rama Narayanan]] who left the TFPC. *May 2011 - M. A. Ramadurai stepped into replace Guhunathan following his departure, with G. Siva staying on as secretary and Angamuthu Shanmugam as treasurer.<ref>http://behindwoods.com/tamil-movie-news-1/jan-12-04/fefsi-prodcuers-council-27-01-12.html</ref> *June 2012 - Director [[Ameer (director)|Ameer]] defeated veteran director [[Visu]] to lead the council in the FEFSI president elections. Siva was re-elected as secretary and Shanmugam as treasurer.<ref>http://www.indiaglitz.com/ameer-becomes-fefsi-president-tamil-news-83017</ref><ref>http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/tamil/article547012.ece</ref>
== See also == * [[Tamil Film Producers Council]] * [[Nadigar Sangam]] (South Indian Artistes' Association)
== References == {{reflist}}
