Orlando Eric Street were cast as First Lady [[Mamie Eisenhower]] and Barack Obama, respectively, but did not appear in the finished film.{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Kam|title=Two-time Oscar-nominee talks about his latest film Lee Daniels' 'The Butler'|url=http://baystatebanner.com/news/2013/aug/15/two-time-oscar-nominee-talks-about-his-latest-film/|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Bay State Banner|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben|title=Lee Daniels pleads with Warner Bros to retain title of The Butler|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2013/jul/04/lee-daniels-warner-brothers-the-butler|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=July 4, 2013}}{{cite news|title='The Butler' Poster: Lee Daniels' New Film Fits Massive Cast List On New One-Sheet|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/03/the-butler-poster_n_3366504.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=June 3, 2013}} ==Production== ===Development=== [[Danny Strong]]'s screenplay is inspired by Wil Haygood's ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' article "A Butler Well Served by This Election".{{cite news |last=Haygood |first=Wil |title=A Butler Well Served by This Election|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/06/AR2008110603948_pf.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 7, 2008}}{{cite web |author=The Reliable Source | date= August 6, 2013 | title= No, President Obama isn't doing a cameo in 'The Butler' | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/wp/2013/08/06/no-president-obama-isnt-doing-a-cameo-in-the-butler/ |department=Reliable Source (blog) | work=[[The Washington Post]] | accessdate=August 8, 2013}} The project received initial backing in early 2011, when producers Laura Ziskin and Pam Williams approached [[Sheila Johnson]] for help in financing the film. After reading Danny Strong's screenplay, Johnson pitched in her own $2.7 million before bringing in several African-American investors. However, Ziskin died from cancer in June 2011. This left director Daniels and producing partner Hilary Shor to look for further producers on their own. They started with [[Cassian Elwes]], with whom they were working on [[The Paperboy (2012 film)|''The Paperboy'']]. Elwes joined the list of producers, and started raising funding for the film. In spring 2012, Icon U.K., a British financing and production company, added a $6 million guarantee against foreign pre-sales. Finally the film raised its needed $30 million budget through 41 producers and executive producers, including Earl W. Stafford, Harry I. Martin Jr., Brett Johnson, [[Michael Finley]], and Buddy Patrick. Thereafter, as film production started [[Weinstein Co.]] picked up U.S. distribution rights for the film. David Glasser, Weinstein Co. COO, called fund raising as an independent film, "a story that's a movie within itself."{{cite web| title = Why 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' Has 41 Producers| url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-lee-daniels-butler-has-605011|date=August 14, 2013| accessdate = August 15, 2013|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}{{cite web| title = Lee Daniels' The Butler: The film with FORTY ONE producers: How a host of stars and entrepreneurs raised $30m to fund The Butler |work=[[Daily Mail]] | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2394397/Lee-Daniels-The-Butler--The-film-FORTY-ONE-producers-How-host-stars-entrepreneurs-raised-30m-fund-The-Butler.html |date=August 15, 2013| accessdate = August 15, 2013}} [[The Weinstein Company]] acquired the distribution rights for the film after [[Columbia Pictures]] put the film in [[Turnaround (filmmaking)|turnaround]].{{cite web |last=Brevet |first=Brad |title=New Look at 'The Butler' as the Weinstein Co. Picks It Up for Distribution |url=http://www.ropeofsilicon.com/weinstein-co-butler-distribution-whitaker-daniels/ |publisher=Ropes of Silicon |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |date=September 24, 2012}}{{cite news |last=Kit |first=Borys |title=Columbia tells White House butler story |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/columbia-tells-white-house-butler-123281 |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=November 19, 2008}} The film's title was up for a possible rename due to a [[Motion Picture Association of America]] claim from [[Warner Bros.]], which had inherited from the defunct Lubin Company a now-lost 1916 silent short film with the same name.{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Ted |title=Harvey Weinstein Has Already Won 'The Butler' Battle (Opinion) |url=https://variety.com/2013/biz/biz/the-butler-title-tiff-why-weinstein-is-already-victorious-1200560460/ |accessdate=July 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=July 9, 2013}} The case was subsequently resolved with the MPAA granting The Weinstein Company permission to add Daniels' name in front of the title, under the condition that his name was "75% the size of ''The Butler''{{-"}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/toldja-mpaa-oks-weinstein-co-to-use-lee-daniels-the-butler/ |title=TOLDJA! Weinstein Co. Can Title Its Movie 'Lee Daniels' The Butler', If It Wants |date=July 19, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 23, 2013}} On July 23, 2013, the distributor unveiled a revised poster, displaying the title as ''Lee Daniels' The Butler''.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/weinstein-co-unveils-new-poster-for-lee-daniels-the-butler-to-comply-with-mpaa/ |title=Weinstein Co Unveils New Poster For 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' To Comply With MPAA |author=The Deadline Team |date=July 23, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 23, 2013}} ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] started in June 2012 in [[New Orleans]]. Production was originally scheduled to wrap in early August 2012 but was delayed by the impact of [[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]].{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Mike|title=Tropical Storm Isaac chases 'The Butler' away, as film suspends production|url=http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2012/08/tropical_storm_isaac_chases_th.html|newspaper=The Times-Picayune|date=August 27, 2012}} ==Reception== === Box office performance === In its opening weekend, the film debuted in first place with $24.6 million.{{cite news|last=Kilday|first=Gregg|title=Box Office Report: 'The Butler' Tops the Field With $25 Million|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-report-butler-tops-608689|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 18, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=Weekend Box Office: 'The Butler' Opens To $25m, 'Kick-Ass 2', 'Jobs', And 'Paranoia' Crash|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2013/08/18/weekend-box-office-the-butler-opens-to-25m-kick-ass-2-jobs-paranoia-crash/|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=Forbes|date=August 18, 2013}} The film topped the North American box office in its first three consecutive weeks.{{cite news|last=Cunningham|first=Todd|title=Oprah Winfrey's 'The Butler' Powers Past 'One Direction' for 3rd Straight Box-Office Win|url=http://mc-3596-1705542522.us-west-2.elb.amazonaws.com/movies/article/oprah-winfrey-s-butler-powers-past-one-direction-3rd-straight-box-office-win-114621|accessdate=September 2, 2013|newspaper=The Wrap|date=September 2, 2013}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Box Office Report: 'The Butler' Wins Again With $17 Million, Crosses $50 Million|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-report-butler-wins-614083|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 25, 2013}} The film has grossed $116.6 million in Canada and the United States, it earned $51.1 million elsewhere, for a total of $167.7 million. ===Critical response=== ''The Butler'' received mostly positive reviews from critics, with a 71% rating on the [[film critic]] aggregate site [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 175 reviews. The site's consensus says, "Gut-wrenching and emotionally affecting, ''Lee Daniels' The Butler'' overcomes an uneven narrative thanks to strong performances from an all-star cast."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lee_daniels_the_butler/ |title=''Lee Daniels' The Butler'' (2013) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |date=August 16, 2013 |accessdate=August 16, 2013}} Another review aggregator, [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Normalization (statistics)|normalized]] rating out of 100 top reviews from mainstream critics, calculated a score of 66 based on 47 reviews, indicating "generally positive reviews".{{cite web|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/lee-daniels-the-butler|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=August 16, 2013}} [[Todd McCarthy]] praised the film saying, "Even with all contrivances and obvious point-making and familiar historical signposting, Daniels' ''The Butler'' is always engaging, often entertaining and certainly never dull."{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler: Film Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/butler/review/601991|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 9, 2013}} [[Richard Roeper]] lauded the film's casting in particular, remarking that "Forest Whitaker gives the performance of his career".{{cite news|last=Roeper|first=Richard|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=http://www.richardroeper.com/reviews/leedanielsthebutler.aspx|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Richard Roeper & The Movies}} [[Rolling Stone (magazine)|''Rolling Stone'']] also spoke highly of Whitaker writing that his "reflective, powerfully understated performance...fills this flawed film with potency and purpose."{{cite news|last=Travers|first=Peter|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/lee-daniels-the-butler-20130815|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Rolling Stone|date=August 15, 2013}} [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] wrote that "Daniels develops a strong sense of the inner complexities and contradictions of the civil-rights landscape."{{cite news|last=Foundas|first=Scott|title=Film Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/lee-daniels-the-butler-review-forest-whitaker-oprah-winfrey-1200575215/|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=August 8, 2013}} ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film three out of four stars and noted that "It's inspiring and filled with fine performances, but the insistently swelling musical score and melodramatic moments seem calculated and undercut a powerful story."{{cite news|last=Puig|first=Claudia|title='The Butler' is mannered and moving|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2013/08/15/the-butler-review/2581949/|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=August 15, 2013}} Miles Davis of the ''[[New York Tribune]]'' gave the film a negative review, claiming the film to be "[[Oscar bait]]", a cliche film designed to attract Oscar nominations."The Butler Review", New York Tribune, 2013. [[Kenneth Turan]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' was more negative; "An ambitious and overdue attempt to create a Hollywood-style epic around the experience of black Americans in general and the civil rights movement in particular, it undercuts itself by hitting its points squarely on the nose with a 9-pound hammer."{{cite news|last=Turan|first=Kenneth|title=Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' significant but often contrived|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-review-the-butler,0,581076.story|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=August 15, 2013}} Several critics compared the film's historical anecdotes and sentimentality to [[Forrest Gump (film)|''Forrest Gump'']].{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=John|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' movie review|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/lee-daniels-the-butler-movie-review/2013/08/14/a8976a42-0443-11e3-9259-e2aafe5a5f84_story.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Rodriguez|first=Rene|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' (PG-13)|url=http://www.miami.com/039lee-daniels039-butler039-pg-13-article|accessdate=August Butler'|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/forest-whitaker-shines-as-the-butler/article_9622adf4-b80a-584c-b0ec-6dcb97a840b2.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=St. Louis generation of people who were talented and skilled. But because of [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow]] and because of [[discrimination]], there was only so far they could go."{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben |title=Barack Obama 'teared up' watching Oscar-tipped drama The Butler |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/aug/28/barack-obama-oscar-tipped-drama-butler |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 28, 2013}} === Accolades === {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Direction & Production Design |Diane Lederman, Tim Galvin |{{nom}} |} ===Historical accuracy=== Regarding historical accuracy, Eliana Dockterman wrote in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'': "Allen was born on a [[Virginia]] plantation in 1919, not in Georgia.... In the movie, Cecil Gaines grows up on a cotton field in Macon, where his family comes into conflict with the white farmers for whom they work. What befalls his parents on the cotton field was [[Stereotypes of African Americans|added for dramatic effect]].... Though tension between father and son over civil rights issues fuels most of the drama in the film, [Eugene Allen's son] Charles Allen was not the radical political activist that Gaines's son is in the movie."{{cite news|last=Dockterman |first=Eliana |title=The True Story of The Butler: Fact vs. Fiction in Lee Daniels' The Butler |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/08/16/what-the-butler-really-saw/ |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 16, 2013}} Particular criticism has been directed at the film's accuracy in portraying President [[Ronald Reagan]]. While Alan Rickman's performance generated positive reviews, the director and screenwriters of the film have been criticized for depicting Reagan as indifferent to civil rights and his reluctance to associate with the White House's black employees during his presidency. According to [[Michael Reagan]], the former president's son, "The real story of the White House butler doesn't imply racism at all. It's simply Hollywood liberals wanting to believe something about my father that was never there."{{cite news|last=Bond|first=Paul|title=President Reagan's Son Attacks 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/president-reagans-son-attacks-lee-614568 |accessdate=August 28, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 26, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/aug/29/the-butler-ronald-reagan-not-racist|publisher=The Guardian|title=The Butler falsely portrays Ronald Reagan as racist, says son|date=August 29, 2013|accessdate=September 1, 2013}}{{cite news|publisher=Newsmax|title=The Butler from Another Planet|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Reagan/Butler-Reagan-Oprah-Allen/2013/08/22/id/521814|date=August 27, 2013|first=Michael|last=Reagan|accessdate=December 25, 2013}} [[Paul Kengor]], one of President Reagan's biographers, also attacked the film, saying, "I've talked to many White House staff, cooks, housekeepers, doctors, and Secret Service over the years. They are universal in their love of Ronald Reagan." In regard to the president's initial opposition to sanctions against [[apartheid]] in South Africa, Kengor said, "Ronald Reagan was appalled by apartheid, but also wanted to ensure that if the apartheid regime collapsed in South Africa that it wasn't replaced by a Marxist-totalitarian regime allied with Moscow and Cuba that would take the South African people down the same road as Ethiopia, Mozambique, and, yes, Cuba. In the immediate years before Reagan became president, 11 countries from the Third World, from Asia to Africa to Latin America, went Communist. It was devastating. If the film refuses to deal with this issue with the necessary balance, it shouldn't deal with it at all."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lee-daniels-butler-reagan-biographers-608233|title=Lee Daniels' 'The Butler': Reagan Biographers Slam President's Portrayal|work=The Hollywood Reporter.com|date=August 16, 2013|accessdate=September 1, 2013}} ==See also== * ''[[Backstairs at the White House]]'', a 1979 miniseries with a similar theme * [[African-American Civil Rights Movement (1954–68) in popular culture]] * [[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]] * [[List of black films of the 2010s]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.weinsteinco.com/sites/leedanielsthebutler/ Official website] * {{IMDb title|1327773|The Butler}} * {{mojo title|butler|The Butler}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|lee_daniels_the_butler|The Butler}} * {{metacritic film|lee-daniels-the-butler|The Butler}} {{Lee Daniels|state=expanded}} {{Danny Strong}} {{African-American Civil Rights Movement}} {{Portal bar|2010s|African Americans|Film in the United States|Government of the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Butler}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s historical films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American historical films]] [[Category:American political drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Lee Daniels]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:African-American civil rights movement (1954–68) in film]] [[Category:Films about politicians]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Dwight D. {{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} '''''The Mythic Circle''''' is an illustrated fiction magazine published annually by the [[Mythopoeic Society]] containing short fiction and poetry.
==History and profile== Founded in 1987 by [[Sherwood Smith]] and Lynn Maudlin, ''The Mythic Circle'' started as a quarterly [[zine]] designed to function as a writers' workshop in print and featured a very active letters column.<ref name=myth/> After several years the enthusiastic submissions of aspiring writers and the challenge of publishing on a quarterly schedule took their toll and the [[zine]] changed to thrice-annually, then twice-annually, and finally became an annual publication.<ref name=myth>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.mythsoc.org/mythic-circle/mythic-circle-history.htm|work=Mythopoeic Society|accessdate=20 December 2015}}</ref> After Sherwood Smith and Lynn Maudlin retired as co-editors, Tina Cooper served as editor for several years with Lynn Maudlin continuing as production editor.
The current editor is Gwenyth Hood; [http://www.mythsoc.org/mythic-circle/mythic-circle-submissions.htm/ submissions information] is available via the Mythopoeic Society website.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.mythsoc.org/mythic-circle.htm/ The Mythic Circle homepage] *[http://www.worldcat.org/title/mythic-circle/oclc/30744812 WorldCat record]

{{Infobox single | | Name = The Toronto Song | Cover = | Artist = [[Three Dead Trolls in a Baggie]] | from Album = Con Troupo Comedius | B-side = | Released = | Format = | Recorded = | Genre = [[comedy music|comedy]] | Length = | Label = | Writer = [[Wes Borg]],
Joe Bird,
Neil Grahn,
Cathleen Rootsaert | Producer = | Certification = | Chart position = | Last single = | This single = | Next single = }} '''"The Toronto Song"''' is a comedy song by [[Canadians|Canadian]] comedy group [[Three Dead Trolls in a Baggie]]. It is one of many songs (including "The White House Burned (The War of 1812)") the Trolls recorded that are often mistakenly attributed to [[The Arrogant Worms]]. Originally on the ''Con Troupo Comedius'' [[cassette tape]], "The Toronto Song" also appears on the CD ''Skit Happens'', a [[greatest hits]] collection of Three Dead Trolls skits. Before the tape, the song had spread across Canada but most listeners didn't know the song's name. It was (and still is) often believed to be called '''"Toronto Sucks", "The Ontario Song"''', or '''"Ontario Sucks"'''. The song starts with the Trolls (who are from [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]]) saying how much they hate the city of [[Toronto]], its people, [[shanty towns]], and landmarks. They then realize they hate all of [[Ontario]], and finally all of Canada (minus Alberta, but including [[Calgary]]). The criticisms of other parts of Canada range from practical ("[[Prince Edward Island]] is too small") to absurd ("[[Manitoba]]'s [[population density]] is 1.9 people per square kilometre. Isn't that stupid?"). The song is primarily poking fun at the popular Canadian activity of insulting Toronto and to a lesser extent Albertan pride and the [[Battle of Alberta|Edmonton-Calgary rivalry]]. The song was recorded with only a couple guitars. Later, a remake of the song, entitled "The Toronto Song 2001", had a full band performing the music and included a guitar solo and different banter. It was featured in the [[mockumentary]] film ''[[Let's All Hate Toronto]]''. One minor error in the song is a mention of "the Ontario Zoo", which does not exist. Toronto does have a zoo, but it is called the [[Toronto Zoo]]. This is corrected in the 2001 remake where the lyric is changed to "Metro Zoo" (the zoo was originally called the "Metropolitan Toronto Zoo"). ==See also== *[[Alberta separatism]] *[[Western alienation]] *[[Toronto-Montreal rivalry]] *[[Battle of Alberta]] ==External links== *[http://www.deadtroll.com Three Dead Trolls in a Baggie official website] {{Unreferenced|date=December 2006}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Toronto Song}} [[Category:Canadian comedy songs]] [[Category:Culture of Edmonton]] [[Category:Culture of Toronto]] [[Category:Regionalism (politics)]] [[Category:Songs about cities]] [[Category:Songs about Canada]] [[Category:Year of song missing]]
